# Description

This C++ version is really just C plus namespaces. Namespaces are the only feature of C++ that is used. The Rust version will come later.

First inside a working deirectory build the C++ version of MIRACL core (https://github.com/miracl/core), selecting support for C25519, NIST256, NIST384, RSA2048 and RSA4096.

This library does all the crypto, and can be regarded as a "placeholder" as we may in the future replace its functionality from other sources.

Then copy the contents of this archive to the same directory, in particular client.cpp and tls*.*

Build the client app by 

	g++ -O2 client.cpp tls_keys_calc.cpp tls_sockets.cpp tls_hash.cpp tls_scv.cpp tls_cert_chain.cpp tls_parse_octet.cpp x509.cpp core.a -o client

Then execute the client process as for example

	client mail.protonmail.com

The (commented and slightly edited) output should look something like

	Hostname= mail.protonmail.com
	ip= 185.70.41.130
	Private key= 0x0f3e3d3c3b3a3938373635343332312f9d155815b664df4bbea56f6b986955a5
	Client Public key= 0x358072d6365880d1aeea329adf9121383851ed21a28e3b75e965d0d2cd166254

	Client Hello= 206 
	Client Hello sent
	Server Random= ddbbf1719e1bd7a95956fa16e29071098cc86e12da9f77b37fc75c44bef6f709
	Cipher suite= 1302
	Key Share = 001d
	Server Public Key= c1626b8e292e540995d3858a4a614e69932fbe2b25e8ff24a16d6531480ff515
	Server Hello received
	Server Hello= 122 020000760303ddbbf1719e1bd7a95956fa16e29071098cc86e12da9f77b37fc75c44bef6f70920e0e1e2e3e4e5e6e7e8e9eaebecedeeeff0f1f2f3f4f5f6f7f8f9fafbfcfdfeff130200002e002b0002030400330024001d0020c1626b8e292e540995d3858a4a614e69932fbe2b25e8ff24a16d6531480ff515

	Server Cert Verification OK
	Data is verified

Try it out on your favourite websites. It will abort if TLS1.3 is not supported. 
At this stage the tool is still very fragile (only tested and debuggd aginst 4 websites!), and would be expected to often fail.
